data.text: Introduction

1.1. This policy has been written in conjunction with BS ISO/IEC 27002:2005 Information technology -- Security techniques -- Code of practice for information security controls in order to define the parameters for authorised access to the Trust's information systems and infrastructure.

1.2. The Trust recognises that it must demonstrate the importance of its responsibilities in controlling access to information systems to third parties, the Department of Health, the Audit Commission, Care Quality Commission and the NHS. Wherever possible the Trust will endeavour to implement recommendations for the protection of such data and other information.

1.3. Under no circumstances are any unauthorised persons allowed to access the Trust computer network and no authorised user is permitted to allow unauthorised persons to use their logon credentials. Staff that have been given legitimate access will only use their active directory account identification for the purposes of their employment and all activity is logged and subject to audit.
1.4. Any unauthorised access to systems and/or information that has not been expressly permitted will be a breach of this policy and subject to disciplinary or legal proceedings.
Scope

2.1. The purpose of this policy is to inform all staff of the access controls to IT hardware, infrastructure and information systems. It will also describe what the Trust deems to be an acceptable usage of IT, including internet use, in order to ensure staffs are aware of their managerial, operational and personal responsibilities.
2.2. Access to all Trust patient information assets must be on the basis of a staff member's job based roles. No access will be given to any system, until authorisation has been provided.

2.3. This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

2.4. This policy applies to all authorised users of the Trust's computer network (including all permanent and temporary employees of the Trust, agency staff, agents, subcontractors, consultants, and third party vendors).
2.5. The document will outline; Users responsibilities, Accessing systems, Access for locum and temporary staffs out of hours and Acceptable usage of systems and Internet.

data.text: Roles & Responsibilities
4.1. Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1. Digital Services Performance & Accountability Group – to review policies and recommend for group approval.
4.1.2. Information Governance Committee – to review any instances of non-compliance to stated policy.
4.1.3. Joint Document Management Group – to ratify polices
4.2. Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust

4.2.1. Chief Executive – as the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
4.2.2. Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious  information  risk  management  issues  are  brought  to  the  Board  for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.3. Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Site Director for each Trust is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PCD processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PCD.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PCD where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
4.2.4. Clinical Directors (CD's) / Associate Clinical Directors (ACDs) and Head Nurses – as senior leaders at each Trust they have responsibility for:
Acting as Information Asset Owners (IAO) for systems within their local area of management.
Compliance with the requirements of this policy within their local area of
management.
Ensuring staff within their management remit undertake mandatory information governance and other relevant training.
Overseeing the reporting of breaches of this policy resulting in information security or health and safety incidents on Trust incident reporting system.
Overseeing the investigation of reported breaches of this policy, making sure lessons learned are shared and appropriate changes in practice are implemented.
4.2.5. Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for development and updating of IT Security Policies and management of IT Infrastructure.
4.2.6. Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for information governance.
4.2.7. Registration Authority (RA) Manager
Ensure all aspects of registration services and operations are performed in accordance with national policies and procedures.
Oversee that all services and operations conform to Trust policies and procedures where these specify additional safeguards over and above national requirements.
Appoint RA agents and make sure all are adequately trained to carry out duties.
Ensure effective controls are in place relating to the issue and maintenance of Smart Cards.
Notify the Caldicott Guardian and SIRO of any potential risks associated with the management and use of Smart Cards.
Report incidents via the Trust's risk management / incident reporting process.
Overseeing that all Trust appointed RA sponsors are trained in their responsibilities including, where appropriate, unlocking Smart Cards and issuing fall back cards.
4.2.8. Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
Authorising new user accounts, ensuring that the IT Service Desk informed of user changes.
Notifying HR promptly of new starters and leavers using the relevant HR process, including staff transfers and secondments
Ensuring that subordinate staff return Trust assets to them during their notice period.
Determining which individuals are to be given authority to access specific information systems. The level of access to specific systems should be on a job function need, independent of status;

Ensuring that the relevant IAA's/user system managers are advised immediately about staff changes affecting computer access (e.g. job function changes/leaving department or organisation) so that passwords may be withdrawn/deleted.
4.2.9. Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Ensuring personal compliance with this policy
Compliance with related Information Governance/IT Cyber Security and incident reporting policies
Keeping their password private and not sharing their logon credentials with anyone else
Taking good care of their Single Sign-on/RA card and not sharing with anyone else
Logging off when computer access is no longer required
Due diligence in accessing all information including PII and PID
Returning all IT assets to their Line Manager on leaving the employ of the Trust
Reporting lost/ stolen SSO cards, remote access tokens or Trust equipment.
4.2.10. Information Asset Administrators (IAA)

The IAA is an operational member of staff with a high level of working knowledge of the business functions of the area and use of the information assets, usually department heads, system super-users or system managers.
All IAA's have a responsibility to ensure that access is granted (following confirmation of training), updated and withdrawn as required in a timely manner.
Policy Requirements
5.1. New Accounts (Registration)
5.1.1. New accounts need to be created for new members of staff and the request must be made via the IT Service Desk or completed through the IT Self-service Portal where available.
5.1.2. The substantive line manager must initiate and authorise new account requests and the identity of the person will be verified by HR as part of new starters procedures.
5.1.3. Formal recording of the documentation should be included as part of the Trust's service desk processes in place at the time.
5.2. Suspending/Disabling User Accounts
5.2.1. Line managers or HR managers may request that user accounts are suspended, these requests should be in via email from an appropriately authorised manager as follows;

Account suspension for investigative and disciplinary proceedings will occur as soon as reasonably practicable after the IT Service Desk is notified and it is duly authorised by a member of the HR Department.
Account suspension for long-term sickness absence and maternity leave must be notified to the IT Service Desk by the line manager of the member of staff concerned.

For staff leaving the Trust their Active Directory and email accounts will be automatically disabled after their record is updated on ESR at Southend or once the team have been notified by HR at Mid Essex and Basildon.

table_items.text: At point of notification or during periodic review whichever is soonest
From maternity leave start (if notified) for a maximum of 13 months
Following periodic reviews of accounts where password lapsed greater than 6months

data.text: 5.2.2. The Head of IT reserves the right to raise further enquiries where the nature of the suspension is unclear. Should there be an incident which cannot be classified as above, the final decision will come down to a final determination by the HR Department.
5.3. Amending/Updating Accounts
5.3.1. Changes to existing user accounts must be requested via the IT Portal and approved by the appropriate line manager or IAO/IAA.
5.3.2. Where additional systems or network drives access for users is being requested this should be raised via the IT Portal with appropriate approvals from line manager or IAO/IAA.
5.4. Users Permissions and Access

5.4.1. Permission and access to information throughout the Trust will be on the premise that; ‘Everything is generally forbidden, unless expressly permitted' however it is also stressed that users are responsible for ensuring that they only access information where it is appropriate for their role

5.4.2. Initial system privileges will be limited to a general departmental network drive, email account and a home directory only. Access may only be extended by the authorised line manager completing and submitting the necessary request and authorisation for extended access through the IT Self-service Portal. If access falls under the jurisdiction of another directorate, business unit or department then authorisation will be required from a senior member of staff or IAO from that area.

5.4.3. Line managers, as part of their managerial role, should periodically review users access; this information may be provided by the IT Department upon request. In order to encourage regular reviews of users access it is recommended that this is undertaken during appraisal or as a matter of course when job functions and job descriptions are changed/altered due to operational reasons.

5.4.4. Where it is known that a member of staff only requires temporary access (eg for a secondment), the planned end date should be added in the appropriate AD date field so that the extra permissions may be automatically withdrawn at the appropriate time. Line managers are required to inform the IT service desk of any changes to the end dates previously identified, ie secondment extensions.
5.4.5. Access to information systems will only be granted upon confirmation that the user has been trained.
5.5. Email Address

5.5.1. Typically all accounts are created with a Trust email address in order that members of staff can receive electronic mail communication. If this is not required (for example in respect of a third party contractor) then this should be indicated when making the access request.
5.5.2. Users should refer to the Trust Email policy which sets out the expectations of the use and conduct of staff in relation to Trust and NHS email systems.
5.6. Single Sign-on (SSO)

5.6.1. Southend site has implemented a SSO solution that provides access by conventional password or by using contactless ID badges to the Trust network and those application systems ‘profiled' i.e. configured, to accept single sign-on access.

5.6.2. The rapid card access facility operates over a four hour ‘grace period' initiated by manually typing a password. During the ‘grace period' a single tap of the card on a reader provides access. In the absence of a card reader the password is entered in the normal manner.
5.6.3. These arrangements do not impact the underpinning Active Directory account configuration described in this Policy.
5.7. Change Password Functionality
5.7.1. The current Trust Password Management System allows enrolled users to change their own password at will by correctly answering previously defined questions and answers.
5.7.2. The SSO solution at Southend has the ability for users to change their passwords at will; this service also extends to ‘profiled' application systems.
5.8. Best Practice Password Management
5.8.1. Users have a responsibility to use appropriate best practice in respect of their Trust logon credentials, including RA and SSO cards. Please refer to the Trust Password policy.
5.8.2. Users should also refer to the Trust Password policy which sets out the expectations of the use and conduct of staff in relation to Trust and NHS systems.
5.9. Clear Screen Best Practice

5.9.1.  Users must not leave a computer unattended with the screen displaying information. Not only does this potentially give rise to an unauthorised disclosure of confidential information it also provides an opportunity for a third party to take action in your name for which you are legally responsible.
5.10. Installation of Software on Trust Devices

5.10.1. Users must not install any software onto Trust owned devices unless it has been approved by the IT department prior to install; users may be subject to the Trusts disciplinary proceedings where it is identified that this process has not been followed.
5.10.2. Users should contact the IT service desk for further information or support.
5.11. Mobile & Remote Access

5.11.1. Trust email is available to authorised users via the Trust's Outlook Webmail Access (OWA) service; this can be accessed using the same Active Directory account user name and password combination as when working on-site.
5.11.2. If Mobile or Remote Access is required it can be requested through the IT Self- service Portal.
5.11.3. The arrangements for access are set out in the Trust's Mobile Devices & Remote Access Policy; this policy is in addition to the requirements set out in this document.
5.12. BYOD Access

5.12.1.  The additional arrangements for users wishing to bring their own device and use it for access to Trust systems are set out in Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) Policy and are in addition to the requirements of this policy.
5.13. Confidential Trust Information
5.13.1.  Staff are required to take all necessary steps to prevent unauthorised access to all Trust information. Examples of confidential information include but are not limited to:
Patient / Staff identifiable information
Corporate strategies
Contractual information
Research information and data
5.14. Internet Services
5.14.1. Staff are permitted limited and reasonable access to the internet for personal reasons however this should preferably not take place during working hours.
5.14.2. The amount of time spent on personal matters on the internet should pass the test of “reasonableness” and not interfere with the work that the staff are contracted to carry out.

5.14.3. Staff must not engage in deliberate accessing of offensive, obscene or indecent material from the Internet, such as pornography, racist or sexist material, violent images, or incitement to criminal behaviour.

5.14.4. Postings by employees of the Trust using corporate email addresses to newsgroups on the Internet / Intranet should contain a disclaimer stating that the opinions expressed are strictly their own and not necessarily those of the Trust unless posting is in the course of business duties. See Social Media Policy for further clarity.

5.14.5. Internet access from Trust facilities is subject to monitoring as potentially identified by a security threat or excessive resource usage. Staff should therefore have no expectation of confidentiality in the use of the Internet from Trust facilities.

5.14.6. Staff must not partake in cyber bullying of any individual using any form of Internet communication including social networking sites, bulletin boards and chat rooms. Such bullying is taken as seriously as any other form of bullying and may result in disciplinary action, which could include dismissal in line with the Disciplinary Policy.
5.15. Out of Hours Access for Locums

5.15.1. The Trust is aware of the limitations for the provision of training during out-of-hours and will provide basic details of utilising Patient Information Assets in the pack provided on arrival. It is recognised that some locum staff will have worked in other hospitals and will be familiar with clinical information systems in general.

5.15.2. Staff employed, or otherwise authorised, by the Trust to use patient information systems will not be allowed access until they have read and confirmed they have understood the training documentation handed to them by an authorised member of Trust staff.

5.15.3. The Trust needs to ensure and document that each user is given only such functions as are necessary for them to carry out their job role. In order to protect patient confidentiality, a number of standard user access groups have been created in most of the clinical and patient information systems, which are based on common job roles and functions.

5.15.4. Locum Staff not directly employed by the Trust will be given similar access rights to Trust staff in the appropriate staff group, but normally on a read only basis, and subject to organisational sign off.

5.15.5. The Site Management Team at Basildon and Southend, and the Medical Staffing team (site security office out of hours) at Mid Essex, are be responsible for issuing the Locum their pack which will include:
Documentation relating to basic training of the systems
An Information Governance declaration
Generic login and password. The generic login MUST be documented on the Information Governance Declaration.
5.15.6. The Information Governance Declaration must be returned to the IT Service Desk, by the Site Management Team/Medical Staffing teams as appropriate, for auditing purposes.
5.15.7. All Locum accounts issued will have passwords that are reset or revoked at regularly intervals no shorter than 7days.
5.15.8. Long term locums, employed for more than 5 days, are required to have formal training and their own AD account by following the new user account process.
5.16. Access to systems via Integrated Identity Management
5.16.1. Registration of existing and new Staff

Staff members requiring an RA Smartcard for the purpose of their role make an appointment to meet with the team responsible for issuing smartcards. At this face to face meeting a photograph is taken prior to the Smartcard being produced.
5.16.2. Position Based Access Control (PBAC)
The Trust has developed PBAC roles which will be periodically reviewed to ensure that they remain current for the positions with the Trust.
The arrangements for revising or removing PBAC roles are set out in the Trust's Registration Authority Policy.
5.17. Staff Code of Conduct When Accessing the Trust's Network/Systems/Internet

5.17.1. In addition to the requirements set out above, users that have been granted access to Trust systems are required to adhere to a code of conduct regarding the use of systems and cyber security.
5.17.2. Staff that disagree with elements of the code of conduct, or are found to have deliberately disregarded it, may have their access to Trust systems withdrawn.
5.17.3. There generally accepted rules of network etiquette, these include (but are not limited to) the following:

BEING POLITE. Never sending or encouraging others to send abusive messages, nor messages that may tend to disparage or harass others on the basis of gender, race, age, disability, religion, sexual orientation or national origin.
USING APPROPRIATE LANGUAGE. I understand that I am a representative of Our Trust on the Internet.
PARTICIPATING in chain letters, or statements that are defamatory or misleading concerning the Trust or other companies/products or services.
PRIVACY. I will not reveal my home address or personal phone number or the addresses and phone numbers of other employees, nor Patient details of any kind.

ELECTRONIC MAIL. Employees of the Trust have access to e-mail accounts for use in connection with undertaking their contracted role. Inappropriate language or advocacy of illegal activity in e-mail messages originating in the Trust may result in loss of system privileges and/or other disciplinary measures.
DISRUPTIONS. I will not use the network in any way that would disrupt use of the network by others.
5.17.4. The full code of conduct can be found in appendix 1.
5.18. Special Access requirements

5.18.1. It is recognised that in some circumstances it may be appropriate for specific, and specially authorised members of staff to access websites which are normally, as a matter of policy or otherwise, prohibited.

5.18.2. Any such access must be authorised by the Group Head of Digital Services, or the Group Head of Information Governance, or their designated representatives, before any such access takes place. This is not only to ensure that no adverse inferences can be drawn against staff but also to ensure that consideration is given as to the most appropriate manner in which such access should be given.
5.18.3. Any access must be carried out in such a manner to ensure that other staffs are not impacted by the material being viewed.
Training Requirements
6.1. Staff are required to complete IG training as part of their annual mandatory training obligations.
6.2. Between annual training requirements staff are to ensure that they keep up to date regarding IT or Cyber security update emails and messages published in staff circulars.
6.3. If there are any concerns regarding the content or implication of this policy they should be directed to the IT Service Desk.
Monitoring & Audit

7.1.2. Where breaches of this policy are identified, either through monitoring or incident investigation, staff may be subject to Trust disciplinary policies and processes.

Appendix 1, Employee Code of Conduct
for Access to the Trust's Network/Systems/Internet

Electronic information services (Network/Systems/Internet) are available to Staff of Mid Essex Hospitals NHS Trust (The Trust). The Trust strongly believes in the value of such electronic services and recognises their potential to support the organisation and the delivery of high quality patient care. Our goal in providing this service is to promote excellence by facilitating research, innovation, and communication.

Staff access will be granted for work purposes and will be monitored by the Trust. As employees of the Trust, and as representatives of the Trust in the global electronic community, staffs are required to abide by relevant Trust policies regarding the use of systems and cyber security.

You will be issued the appropriate access to the Trust Network, systems and Internet on the understanding that you have read the following code of conduct, and that you will adhere to it and the appropriate Trust policies regarding the use of systems and cyber security.
If you DO NOT agree to the following code of conduct, the Trust  may revoke access to Trust systems.
The Staff Code of Conduct for Access to the Trust's Network/Systems/Internet is as follows:

I understand that transmission of any material in violation of any law is prohibited. This includes, but is not limited to copyrighted material, threatening or obscene material or material protected by trade secret, or Patient confidentiality.
I will not use the Trust's Internet access for commercial activities, online gambling, accessing, displaying or disseminating pornography.
I will not use the Trust's Internet access for product advertisement.
I will not use the Trust's Internet access for downloading, using or distributing copyrighted materials, software or executable programs, without proper authorisation.

I am aware that the inappropriate use of electronic information resources can be a breach of my contract of employment and criminal law and that I can dismissed and/or be prosecuted for violating those laws.

BEING POLITE. Never sending or encouraging others to send abusive messages, nor messages that may tend to disparage or harass others on the basis of gender, race, age, disability, religion, sexual orientation or national origin.
USING APPROPRIATE LANGUAGE. I understand that I am a representative of Our Trust on the Internet.
PARTICIPATING in chain letters, or statements that are defamatory or misleading concerning the Trust or other companies/products or services.
PRIVACY. I will not reveal my home address or personal phone number or the addresses and phone numbers of other employees, nor Patient details of any kind.

ELECTRONIC MAIL. Employees of the Trust have access to e-mail accounts for use in connection with undertaking their contracted role. Inappropriate language or advocacy of illegal activity in e-mail messages originating in the Trust may result in loss of system privileges and/or other disciplinary measures.
DISRUPTIONS. I will not use the network in any way that would disrupt use of the
network by others.
